video_title: Agents Unleashed Podcast Ep. 4 - Would You Give An AI Agent Your Credit Card?
description:
This is episode four of the Agents Unleashed podcast — the show that filters the signal from the noise in the fast-paced world of agentic AI.

This episode dives into a big week for AI payments and open source: Visa, MasterCard, and Coinbase all announced new tools to enable AI agents to make and receive payments, Mark Zuckerberg shared insights on Meta’s open source strategy and a flurry of new models from companies like Alibaba, Microsoft, and NVIDIA are pushing the boundaries of what open source can do. 

There's also a look at a new report on open source AI adoption from McKinsey, Mozilla, and the Patrick J. McGovern Foundation.

Chapters

00:00 Introduction
01:16 Mark Zuckerberg's vision for AGI
04:31 Open source vs closed source AI debate
05:40 Visa and Mastercard’s plans for AI payments
07:26 Coinbase's HTTP payment infrastructure
08:05 Open source AI adoption trends
09:39 New AI model releases and developments
10:37 Implications for AI ownership and control
11:19 Final thoughts on AI's future impact


Resources mentioned in this episode:

Visa and Mastercard's payments for AI agents: 
https://techcrunch.com/2025/04/30/visa-and-mastercard-unveil-ai-powered-shopping/

Coinbase’s HTTP 402 proposal: https://www.coinbase.com/en-sg/developer-platform/discover/launches/x402

Meta’s open source strategy and Zuckerberg interview: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rYXeQbTuVl0

McKinsey x Mozilla x McGovern report: https://www.mckinsey.com/capabilities/quantumblack/our-insights/open-source-technology-in-the-age-of-ai

Alibaba’s Qwen 3: https://qwenlm.github.io/blog/qwen3
NVIDIA Parakeet: https://venturebeat.com/ai/nvidia-launches-fully-open-source-transcription-ai-model-parakeet-tdt-0-6b-v2-on-hugging-face/?utm_source=chatgpt.com
Microsoft Fi4 Models: https://azure.microsoft.com/en-us/blog/one-year-of-phi-small-language-models-making-big-leaps-in-ai/?utm_source=chatgpt.com
JetBrains Mellum: https://techcrunch.com/2025/04/30/jetbrains-releases-mellum-an-open-ai-coding-model/
DeepSeek Prover V2: https://arxiv.org/html/2504.21801v1

Agents Unleashed is more than a podcast — it's the premier global event series for AI agents. With 77+ speakers and over 2,500 attendees, events have been hosted in 6+ cities worldwide. The next one is happening June 30th in Cannes, France. Learn more at https://olas.network/agents-unleashed.

Sponsored by Olas — the best way to own and monetize your AI agents. Explore more at https://www.olas.network.

Theme music: "Forward" by Grand Project on Pixabay: https://pixabay.com/users/grand_project-19033897/

transcript.aggregated_text: [Music] all right hey welcome back this is episode four of the Agents Unleash podcast it's the show that helps you to filter the signal from the noise in the fast-paced world of Agentic AI i'm your host Thomas Maybry i'm the digital media producer for Valerie one of the core contributors to OLS who is sponsoring this show if you haven't heard of us or you haven't heard of Agents Unleashed let me quickly take a moment to tell you about both ols makes it easy for anyone to own and monetize AI agents and that includes people like you you can learn more about how to do that at ol.network network and Agents Unleashed isn't just a podcast it's also the premier event series for people interested in Agentic AI and AI agents events have been held all over the world with over 77 different speakers and panelists and 2500 inerson attendees to learn more about the events and watch recordings from previous talks and presentations you can go to o.network/agents-uned and by the way the next Agents Unleashed event has just been announced it'll be held June 30th in Can France so save the date and I hope to see you there okay so on today's show we're going to take a look at payments for AI agents with some major announcements from Visa Mastercard Coinbase the role of open source and AI with some fresh insights from Meta CEO Mark Zuckerberg and then take a look at a fresh batch of cutting edge models from companies like Alibaba Microsoft Nvidia and more that's a lot to cover so let's get started okay we'll start with Mark Zuckerberg so in a recent interview with Dorash Patel he shared his perspective on the trajectory of AGI artificial general intelligence and Meta's ambitious endeavors in open source so Zuckerberg's viewpoint isn't solely focused on a distant abstract future for AI he's emphasized several times in his interviews that Meta's focus is on delivering tangible value to users right now he claimed that Meta AI is being used by almost a billion people monthly and that that's happening primarily through WhatsApp the vision that he lays out for AI in these talks and interviews is one where AI is deeply integrated into our lives and our daily routines and where our needs are anticipated and there's a very seamless user experience here's a quote especially once you get the personalization loop going that's going to be the next big thing that's super exciting i'm really big on that he also mentioned a UX that I personally could really easily imagine and that's where we're going to be talking to these models on and off throughout our day and it wouldn't just be limited to chat by the way that could also be through voice which I personally find really compelling this vision of highly personalized AI assistance integrated into our daily lives though it does raise important questions like are we going to own these assistants or just rent them if we're renting AI we're essentially at the mercy of the service provider and we have limited control over how the AI functions how our data is used and even whether we can continue using it at all it's great that Meta's llama models are open source but as that 1 billion via WhatsApp figure highlights the model might be open source but the means of access may not be the same goes for any fine tunes they might create for you and let's not forget that Meta has a long history of mismanaging user data and engaging in problematic patterns around data privacy and ownership with that in mind if these assistants do become deeply integrated into our lives are going to be managing our tasks providing us information making decisions for us the stakes around ownership do become higher a cornerstone of Meta Strategy is these Llama models and these are open source models i'm sure you've heard of them they recently just launched Llama 4 and Zuckerberg said that he's particularly excited about its capabilities he said he's very happy with the first set of Llama releases and that Meta is actively developing models that are optimized for different use cases from efficient low latency models for everyday youth to these massive behemoth models with trillions of parameters he also mentioned that building these powerful AI systems includes a lot of different inputs and one of those is massive computational power he acknowledges the challenges of building the necessary infrastructure explaining if you want to build a gigawatt cluster of compute that just takes time nvidia needs time to stabilize their new generation of systems then you need to figure out the networking around it then you need to build the building you need to get the permitting and you need to get the energy another moment that's been making the rounds lately Zuckerberg has gone on record saying that he believes that sometime in the next 12 to 18 months the majority of code for the Llama development and refinement process will be written by AI agents here's a clip the big one that we're focused on is um building an AI and a machine learning engineer to advance the llama development itself right because I mean our our bet is sort of that in the next year probably you know I don't know maybe half the development is going to be done by AI as as opposed to people and then that will just kind of increase from there so the amount of new models that are being announced and these impressive performance gains seem to indicate to me that these challenges are speed bumps rather than roadblocks especially if we're going to get this development loop where AI agents are writing and iterating and testing code faster than human developers are capable of zuckerberg's also been touching on the open source debate in his interviews which is a crucial theme that directly relates to the concept of AI ownership he noted the increasing prominence of open source models stating the prediction that this would be the year open source generally overtakes closed source as the most used models out there i think that's generally on track to be true so open source offers a pathway to greater user control and ownership and when you make the underlying code and the model accessible this empowers users to better understand modify and potentially even host their own AI systems thereby reducing reliance on these centralized providers this is in direct contrast to the rental model or software as a service where users have limited visibility and control and their access can be revoked at any time getting this UX right is going to be a key challenge that decentralized alternatives just have to nail the big centralized players have already been successful in normalizing these trade-offs in other domains so to be a credible alternative it's going to be incumbent on these decentralized players to really think about both communicating the why of what they do without sacrificing the simplicity and accessibility of a good user experience the tension between renting and owning becomes even more apparent when we consider emerging applications like AI shopping agents so would you let an AI agent use your credit card well if you don't have an answer off the top of your head it's probably time to start thinking about it because this week both Visa and Mastercard announced platforms and projects designed to hook AI agents up to the world of commerce visa intelligent commerce is a platform that enables AI agents to make purchases on your behalf visa's chief product and strategy officer Jack Forsall said "Soon people will have AI agents browse select purchase and manage on their behalf." The platform purportedly allows you to set spending parameters like your preferred merchants and Visa has already partnered with major players like Anthropic IBM Microsoft and OpenAI to get the concept off the ground so the convenience of these AI shopping agents is undeniable but again it's worth considering if they're provided by a centralized platform we may have limited control over their decision-making and logic how they handle our financial data or whether the provider can change the terms of service and even revoke our access of course security is paramount and Visa says that they're addressing these concerns with tokenized credentials identity verification and real-time fraud ID mastercard has also announced a similar initiative theirs is called the agentic payments program and so I think this signals a broader industry trend towards involving AI agents in commerce and payments yorn Lambert chief product officer at Mastercard said that the launch of Mastercard agent pay marks our initial steps in redefining commerce in the AI era so I think these two announcements are actually incredibly good news for AI agents as a whole clearly AI agents are going to need userowned granular access to a variety of payment options whether that's through these big payment processors or decentralized payment rails like the OSME marketplace offers so agents can use safe smart wallets but through the mech marketplace they also have access to Nevermind another payment option where agents can transact with each other through what Nevermind calls universal bartering where they're trading services directly without the use of say dollars as a means of exchange staying in the world of decentralized agent payments on Tuesday Coinbase announced their intent to use HTTP code 402 which stands for payment required to allow for payments to be sent using this existing HTTP infrastructure you're probably familiar with this prefix in the context of web URLs maybe error messages like HTTP 404 what they've done is published a white paper and set up some of the necessary infrastructure to allow developers and by extension AI agents to use these payment rails as a means of sending and receiving value so clearly this idea of payments for AI agents is really taking off and I think it's going to be very exciting to see who builds what and by which path so next I want to share some ideas that I found in a recent report that's a collaboration between McKenzie the Mozilla Foundation and the Patrick J mcgovern Foundation it's called open source technology in the age of AI and in this report they surveyed over 700 technology leaders and developers and they found that the use of open source AI is widespread more than 50% of the respondents reported that they use open source solutions in their data their models or the tool areas of their tech stack i think it's really interesting to see these numbers because as I mentioned before open source AI directly addresses some of these concerns about the rental model if there's more and better open source models then users are more empowered they'll have better control more transparency and they'll also get the ability to customize these AI models to their specific needs the report highlights several compelling advantages i'm going to list them here one is respondents say that they're generally satisfied with open source AI models they cite performance and ease of use as reasons for that they also say that it provides cost benefits the implementation costs are lower and so are the maintenance costs compared with proprietary tools developers also said that they highly value the experience that they get using open source tools they say that it contributes to their overall job satisfaction the report also acknowledges some challenges concerns around cyber security regulatory compliance and intellectual property all of these could be significant barriers to adoption but despite these concerns it seems to me that the outlook for open source AI is overwhelmingly positive you've got the backing of Mark Zuckerberg the people surveyed in this report where by the way 70% of the respondents in the report said that they expected to increase their use of open source AI technologies in the coming years so this brings us back to the cutting edge of AI model development we've been seeing another surge of new models recently and there's been a strong emphasis on open weight open source and also specialization of the type that Mark Zuckerberg has been talking about in these talks and podcasts so here's a quick rundown of some of the recent announcements and what they're reportedly good at and for deepseek has released Prover V2 which is an openweight LLM designed for math proof verification alibaba released Quen 3 which has a focus on hybrid reasoning and Microsoft recently released a suite of new open reasoning models through Fiore nvidia also recently announced Parakeet which is an open- source automatic speech recognition model that has been achieving some very impressive results and JetBrains has also contributed to the space with an open source model called Melon that's especially designed for coding links to articles about all these new models can be found in the description or the show notes by the way so I think it's really exciting to see all these new models come out i'm personally particularly interested in the gains and advances that these new reasoning models have been making if you think about a use case like this predict the agent economy where you have AI agents participating in prediction markets I think it's not hard to imagine that with better models better reasoning you might get better predictions and generate even more highquality synthetic data which can then be used to train the models or maybe even improve the AI coding agents that Mark Zuckerberg has been talking about okay so let's wrap it up for the week as I said in episode 3 it's clear that we're at an inflection point the long-term pursuit of AGI as envisioned by leaders by Mark Zuckerberg is very closely intertwined with the very near-term transformation of all industry including shopping as demonstrated by Visa Mastercard and Coinbase underpinning all of this is the growing power and influence of open source AI and the importance of democratizing and fostering access and collaboration you can see the evidence of that in the Mckenzie report and the release of all these new open source models but let's not forget the crucial layer where everyday people and their needs their autonomy come into the picture all of this news challenges us to think critically about who controls the AI systems we use do we truly own them or are we simply renting them seeding the control of our data our choices and potentially our future autonomy when are we okay with that and when should it give us pause are we doing enough to support the development and exploration of alternatives the choices that we make today about AI development and deployment are going to have profound implications for individual autonomy the distribution of power and society more broadly and if we're going to embrace this transformative power of AI we need to prioritize the principles of ownership transparency and user control the journey ahead is complex to be sure and there's challenges around security ethics and responsible development but the potential upside is huge so let's take a stand and take ownership of it all right that was a lot of news and some big ideas so we'll leave it here for this week if you have any questions for me some suggestions for the show please get in touch i am thomas onx links to all the articles reports and resources that we talked about today can be found in the show notes or the description box if you're watching on YouTube and if you enjoyed today's show please help us grow you can do that by leaving a five-star rating on Spotify or Apple Podcasts give us a thumbs up on YouTube leave a comment and if you know someone at work school or in your personal life who you think would enjoy the show please share this episode with them all right that's a wrap i'll see you next time on the Agents Unleash podcast [Music]
